tossups.question: High spin complexes with this many d electrons contain four unpaired electrons and are therefore paramagnetic. The superacid with the lowest Hammett function has this many fluorine atoms bound to antimony. Compounds containing chromium with this oxidation state are highly carcinogenic. In nuclear reprocessing, uranium is reacted with chlorine trifluoride to produce a uranium compound with this many (*) fluorine atoms. A molecule with “chair” and “boat” conformations has this many carbon atoms. This is the number of ligands in an octahedral complex. Benzene has this many hydrogen atoms and this many carbon atoms. For 10 points, give this number, the atomic number of carbon.

This poet described a “heart melting...like candles” and “life fleeing hushed and gentle like the gazelle” in “Dusk.” Another of her works asks God to save a man from “wicked hands” and cries “You are going to judge me, you know it, Lord!” That work promises to be covered up and then “speak for an eternity” to a man whom she also addressed in “To See Him Again.” This poet described following her mother through a series of black (*) hills in the first section of a collection mourning her mother’s death, “Tala.” This poet’s most famous work declares “From the cold niche where men placed you / I will lower you to the humble and sunny ground” and is addressed to her ex-lover Romelio Ureta. For 10 points, name this Chilean poet of “Desolación” and “Sonnets of Death.”

This artist painted a woman in a blue dress with one unfastened button in the ironically titled The Perfectionist. For Sinclair Lewis’s novel Main Street, this man created a drawing of derelict houses titled Village Slums. One painting by this artist is a portrait of a young man dressed in black with trees in the background and two small nudes to his right. This artist of Arnold Comes of Age and (*) Death on Ridge Road showed a young George Washington with a cherry tree in Parson Weems’ Fable. This painter’s dentist Byron McKeeby and his sister Nan modeled for his most famous work, in which a man holds a pitchfork next to a serious-looking woman. For 10 points, name this American Regionalist painter of American Gothic.

In this election, Elihu B. Washburne received the lowest number of votes. Thomas Hendricks was the running mate for the Democratic candidate in this election. The winner of this election was a successful prosecutor in the Whiskey Ring Scandal, and this was the first election in which the Democrats won the popular vote while (*) losing the electoral vote. During the Republican Convention of this election, Roscoe Conkling made an attempt to challenge James G. Blaine for the Republican nomination. 19 electoral votes were highly disputed in this election that ended Reconstruction, which became known as the Compromise of 1877. For ten points, name the election in which an Electoral Commission allowed Rutherford B. Hayes to defeat Samuel Tilden.

In one of this author’s works, the main character employs a new valet named Curtiss and bequeaths a copy of Othello to the narrator. In a play by this author, a fake policeman attempts to strangle his former teacher at a snowed-in hotel; that play frequently uses the song “Three Blind Mice.” In another of this author’s novels, the unreliable narrator Dr. James (*) Sheppard is revealed to be the blackmailer of Mrs. Ferrars. A group of people discover that none of them knows U.N. Owen in one of this author’s works in which Dr. Armstrong helps Justice Wargrave fake his own death. A novel by this author of Curtain reveals that Ratchett is actually Cassetti, and twelve people are all complicit in his murder. For 10 points, name this author of characters like Hercule Poirot in detective fiction such as The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, And Then There Were None, and Murder on the Orient Express.

This piece was twice recorded completely under the baton of Michael Riesman. This work was premiered by its composer’s namesake ensemble at the Avignon Festival and is unusually scored for two electric organs. One section of this opera named for a Carole King song includes a Christopher Knowles poem read over a soprano saxophone and bass clarinet line. Sections of this opera include “I Feel the Earth Move” and “Mr. (*) Bojangles.” This opera’s three main parts are titled “Train,” “Trial,” and “Spaceship.” This work, Satyagraha, and Akhnaten make up a certain composer’s “Portrait Trilogy”, and it is connected by five intermezzos known as “knee plays.” For 10 points, name this minimalist Philip Glass opera about the titular physicist.

This person interviewed Indian officials while pretending to be a CNN reporter in the early 1990s as part of a $700,000 deal he signed with Pakistan’s Inter-Service Intelligence agency. In 2014, this man became the consultant for the center-left political party Opposition Bloc. Along with Charles Black, Peter Kelly, and Roger Stone, he operated a lobbying firm that represented Jonas (*) Savimbi, Ferdinand Marcos, and Mobutu Sese Seko. While on bail, this man was caught writing an anonymous op-ed about himself with political operative Konstantin Kilimnik. This man was charged with conspiracy against the United States and violation of the Foreign Agents Registration Act, along with his business associate Rick Gates. For 10 points, name this former Trump campaign manager who was indicted by the FBI on October 30, 2017.

Before being elevated to this position, its first occupant worked as a lawyer in the city of Barinas. A man who held this position, Cipriano Castro, refused to pay his country’s debts in 1902, leading to a blockade by Britain, Germany, and Italy. One holder of this position founded the MBR-200 organization, which unsuccessfully attempted to overthrow Carlos Andres Perez. That man created the Fifth Republic Movement, led the (*) PSUV from 2007 until his death, and implemented the Bolivarian Revolution in his country. Riots over food shortages and the arrest of opposition leader Leopoldo Lopez have plagued the current occupant of this position, who won a controversial election against Henrique Capriles to succeed Hugo Chavez. For 10 points, name this position held by Nicolas Maduro.

A much faster repetition of a sequence of cell activations during rest is called a type of “replay” named after this structure; that phenomenon was observed by John O’Keefe. Sharp waves and ripples might occur during sleep in this structure. A sclerosis of this structure was first described by Wilhelm Sommer and occurs in the subiculum and CA1 region of this structure. Neurogenesis occurs at high rates in the dentate gyrus in this structure, and this structure was removed from a patient known as (*) H.M. to treat his epilepsy. Place cells in this structure form a cognitive map used in spatial recognition, while degradation of this region causes amnesia. For 10 points, name this part of the limbic system that stores long term memories and is shaped like a seahorse.

In this book, one person uses a sword to kill King Eglon. That person is Ehud, and he comes after Othniel chronologically. The last five chapters of this Biblical book describe how “there is no king in Israel” through the story of the Levite who offered up his daughter and concubine to be raped and through the story of Micah and Jonathan. The titular people’s leadership (*) ends when Samuel anoints Saul as king. The death of Sisera is prophesied by the only female one of these titular people, Deborah. The last of these people gets blinded by Philistines after Delilah cuts his hair. That man is Samson. For 10 points, name this Biblical book that comes after Joshua, which is about the twelve titular Israelite leaders, including Gideon and Samson.
tossups.answer: Book of Judges [accept “Judges of Israel” or other equivalents; accept Sefer Shoftim] <Mathew>

tossups.question: This conflict began after a man known as Celo (CHEL-LOH) killed the bridegroom’s father at a wedding. The Graz agreement was a failed attempt to end this war, during which a ceasefire was declared by the Washington agreement. Operation Sana and Operation Mistral 2 targeted one side in this conflict, and that side was also targeted by Operation Deliberate Force. Two shellings of Markale Market took place in this war, during which the ARBiH and HVO groups fought the (*) VRS. Alija Izetbegović, Franjo Tuđman, Slobodan Milošević, and Bill Clinton signed the treaty that ended this conflict. During this conflict, Ratko Mladic’s army killed over 8,000 people in the Srebrenica Massacre. For 10 points, name this 1990s Balkan civil war ended by the Dayton Accords.

This novel has a notoriously short sixth chapter in which the protagonist begins “to realize her position in the universe as a human being” and whose style is echoed in its final chapter, repeating that a certain object’s touch is “sensuous” and “encloses the body in its warm embrace.” This novel also features the Farival twins who are renowned for their abilities on the piano. This novel opens with a (*) parrot shouting “Allez-vous en”. The protagonist of this novel cries in disgust when she sees her friend Adele Ratignolle giving birth, falls in love with Robert Lebrun, and soon after drowns herself in the Gulf of Mexico. For 10 points, name this novel about Edna Pontellier, a proto-feminist novel by Kate Chopin.

Techniques such as G-Free defend against an attack where these structures are forced to execute gadgets. That attack is called “return-oriented programming,” which is similar to the “return-to-libc” attack that can target the non-executable types of these structures. Both an algorithm that finds the minimum value in a totally monotone matrix and another that finds the convex hull of a set of points use these data structures. Those algorithms are called SMAWK and (*) Graham’s scan. Canary values can prevent these structures from being “smashed.” Tokens are added to these structures in the shunting-yard algorithm which converts expressions into Reverse Polish Notation. One can “peek” at the top element of these data structures, but more common operations include “push” and “pop.” For 10 points, name these “last in, first out” data structures that may “overflow” in a common error.

Hermes once told Atreus that he could rule this place if the sun were to go backwards. This place was ruled by Sthenelus and Electryon, the sons of the founder of this place, who once dug up a mushroom here. This place also contains a fountain named after that founder. Along with Tiryns, this place has mortarless fortifications built by the Cyclopes. Fighting with the Argives, the founder of this place once defeated (*) Dionysus after Dionysus entered this place. A gate named after lions protects this place and Heracles’ labors were ordered by Eurystheus, the king of this place. Medusa was also decapitated by the eventual founder of this place, Perseus. For ten points, name this kingdom that was once ruled by Agamemnon.

The Joback method for calculating this quantity includes a term where a sum of this quantity for various groups is subtracted by 597.82. Models relating this quantity to temperature, such as those named after Walther and Wright, often include double logarithms. This quantity is directly proportional to temperature to the three-halves power in Sutherland’s formula. One form of this quantity has units of kilograms over meters times seconds, while this quantity is multiplied the Laplacian of velocity in the (*) Navier-Stokes Equations. The Greek letters nu, eta, and mu are used for various forms of this quantity, which is found squared in the denominator of the Grashof number. This quantity is multiplied by radius, velocity, and 6 pi to yield drag in Stokes’ Law, and it is in the denominator of the Reynolds number. For 10 points, name this quantity with dynamic and kinematic forms, a measure of a fluid’s resistance to flow.
tossups.answer: viscosity (accept specific types such as dynamic viscosity, kinematic viscosity, or eddy viscosity) <Hao>

tossups.question: The end of this period included the first labor strike in recorded history. The last ruler of this period was succeeded by a man known as Smendes who ruled from Tanis. A king who ruled near the end of this period won the Battle of Djahy. The siege of Avaris was won by Ahmose I, who began this period. One ruler during this period sent a large trading expedition to the Land of (*) Punt. Another ruler’s wife is believed to have ruled as Neferneferuaten during this period, and that ruler’s own reign is described in the Amarna letters. This period followed the rule of the Hyksos during the Second Intermediate Period, and pharaohs such as Hatshepsut and Akhenaten ruled during it. For 10 points, name this final Egyptian kingdom whose rulers included Ramesses the Great.

In a work with this title, Kallias is infatuated with Autolykos, leading the central figure to remind him of his promise to demonstrate wisdom. In addition to that work by Xenophon, another work with this title is interpreted as a response to the play The Frogs and contains a section where the central concept is related by Diotima. Near the end of that work, (*) Alcibiades claims that he has never been able to seduce one figure as he has no interest in carnal pleasures. In an earlier section of the same work, Aristophanes drunkenly claims that humans were once a creature with two bodies and were split in half by the gods and condemned to search the earth for their other half. For 10 points, name this Platonic dialogue where famous figures such as Socrates engage in a discussion on the nature of love.

The composer of this piece often bought church bells to use in its final movement because standard orchestral bells were unsatisfactory. Its third movement opens with gradually softer G-C timpani strokes and draws from the composer’s setting of St. Anthony of Padua preaching to fish. The first movement of this piece is marked “with complete gravity and solemnity of expression” and was originally written as a symphonic poem called (*) Totenfeier. An alto sings “O red rose!” to open the fourth movement of this work, “Urlicht”, and it includes several settings of Des Knaben Wunderhorn. This piece also sets to music Friedrich Klopstock’s “Die Auferstehung”, which gives this symphony its name. For 10 points, name this second symphony written by Gustav Mahler.
tossups.answer: Resurrection Symphony (or Gustav Mahler’s Symphony No. 2 before mention) <Sivakumar>

tossups.question: In the last chapter of this work, the narrator describes the “loveliest and saddest landscape in the world” and tells the reader to look up at the sky and ask themselves a certain question to “see how everything changes.” In this work, a railroad switchman muses that children are the only ones looking out of the windows of a train before remarking that “They are lucky.” The protagonist of this work learns the meaning of the word “ephemeral” from a (*) geographer, and earlier, he meets a drunkard who drinks to forget that he is ashamed of drinking. A Turkish astronomer is ignored in this work because of his non-Western clothing, and a fox asks to be tamed before saying that “It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.” The protagonist of this work describes destructive baobabs and a vain rose on his home planet. For 10 points, name this poignant novella by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry.
tossups.answer: The Little Prince or Le Petit Prince <Hao>

tossups.question: In one essay collection, this thinker states that the science of economics should be free of value judgements and that economic theories should not be judged by their tautological completeness but by their simplicity and fruitfulness. That collection is Essays in Positive Economics. During a congressional hearing, this thinker stated that multi-price auctions cost the treasury money and favor the dealer community which lead to him advocating for (*) uniform price auctions. In another work, this thinker posited that spending behavior is based on expected income as opposed to actual and he proposed that there is a natural level of unemployment in another work. For ten points name this Chicago School economist who worked with Anna Schwartz on A Monetary History of the United States

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about Cesar Franck. For 10 points each:
parts: Franck was from this country, whose other composers include Guillaume Lekeu and Henri Vieuxtemps.
The most famous piece composed by Franck is an A major sonata for piano and this instrument. Virtuosos of this instrument include Joshua Bell and Itzhak Perlman.
During his time at the Paris Conservatoire, Franck taught this French composer of the tone poem Istar and Symphony on a French Mountain Air.

bonuses.leadin: This technique is often used to show a closed formula for the sum of the first n positive integers. For 10 points each:
answers: Well-Ordering Principle (or WOP, do not accept or prompt on “Well-Ordering Theorem”)
parts: Name this proof technique that involves a base case and a namesake hypothesis.
Induction is equivalent to this statement, which states that every non-empty subset of the positive integers contains a least element.
Induction is closely related to infinite descent, which was used by this mathematician to prove the n=4 case of his namesake Last Theorem.

bonuses.leadin: Several American writers were inspired by bridges. For 10 points each:
answers: The Bridge of San Luis Rey
parts: This poet of “At Melville’s Tomb” collected sections like “Powhatan’s Daughter” in his long poem The Bridge.
An Inca rope bridge collapse witnessed by Brother Juniper in Peru is the focus of this 1927 Thornton Wilder novel.
Peyton Farquhar is hanged from the titular structure in this American author’s short story “An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge.” He also wrote The Devil’s Dictionary.

bonuses.leadin: This work argues that no one can sit next to the bed of a dying child and still believe in God. For 10 points each:
answers: Why I Am Not a Christian
parts: Name this essay that also outlines the reasons why the author does not “think that Christ was the best and wisest of men” and expresses support for Darwinian evolution.
“Why I Am Not a Christian” was written by this British Analytic philosopher who argued against Meinong’s theory of objects in On Denoting.

In this work, Russell argued that because family is important for children, the title things should not be permanent until a child is conceived. In this work, he also argued for trial forms of the title relationships.

bonuses.leadin: Important sources for this battle include the Poem of Pentaur and the Bulletin. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this stalemate between the Egyptian New Kingdom and the Hittite Empire, the largest chariot battle in history.
This pharaoh commanded the Egyptian forces at Kadesh. The temples at Abu Simbel were built during his reign.
This Hittite king moved his capital from Hattusa to Tarhuntassa but is better known for fighting Ramesses II at Kadesh.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about plains, as in the flat landmasses. For 10 points each:
parts: The cities of Tomsk and Novosibirsk can be found in the West Siberian Plain in the Asian part of this large country.
Plateaus on this plain include the Sagamino and Musashino. The Boso Peninsula and Tokyo Bay are located to the south of this plain.
The Kaffiøyra Plain is located in Oscar II Land on this island. This is the largest and only permanently inhabited island in the Svalbard archipelago.

bonuses.leadin: In this model, if the value “J sub i j” equals zero, then two spins are noninteracting. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mathematical model that assigns a spin of plus one or minus one to each site in a lattice. The Potts model is a generalization of this model.
The Ising model describes materials with this property, the strongest type of magnetism. Iron has this property.

The noise associated with this effect can be used in non-destructive evaluation of some magnetic materials. In this effect, ferromagnetic materials become magnetized not continuously, but in small, discrete steps.

bonuses.leadin: Alexander Dubcek tried to carry out reforms in this country. For 10 points each:
answers: Velvet Revolution (do not accept “Velvet Divorce”; prompt on just “Velvet”)
parts: Name this country where the Prague Spring was crushed by the Warsaw Pact.
One-party rule in Czechoslovakia ended following this 1989 event, which resulted in Vaclav Havel’s election as president.
This president, Havel’s predecessor, was forced to resign after the Velvet Revolution. He oversaw the so-called “renormalization” period following the Prague Spring.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about Elizabethan writers. For 10 points each:
answers: Doctor Faustus (do not accept or prompt on “Faust”)
parts: This “Bard of Avon” wrote plays like Twelfth Night and Romeo and Juliet.
This play by Christopher Marlowe opens with the titular University of Wittenburg graduate learning necromancy. At the end of the play, he is dragged off the stage by Mephistopheles.
This other Elizabethan wrote a work of literary criticism titled In Defence of Poesy as well as the sonnet collection Astrophel and Stella.

bonuses.leadin: Name some important figures in the Norse creation myth. For 10 points each:
parts: This figure is the ancestor of all giants. He was born from the venom of the river Élivágar and after his death, the world was fashioned from his body.
This king of the gods is one of the three individuals that killed Ymir. He sits on the throne Hlidskjalf from which he can see into all realms, despite only having one eye.
Two answers required. These are the other two figures who killed Ymir, the brothers of Odin. They gave wit, countenance, speech, hearing, sight, and touch to the first humans, Ask and Embla.

bonuses.leadin: With Gil Evans, this man arranged Joaquin Rodrigo’s Concierto de Aranjuez to open his album Sketches of Spain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this jazz trumpeter who included “So What” and “Freddie Freeloader” on Kind of Blue.
Davis was an early proponent of this genre of jazz more relaxed than bebop. Jerry Mulligan and John Lewis arranged several standards for a Davis album titled for the “birth” of this style.
One of the biggest influences on Birth of the Cool was this pianist, whose namesake orchestra included Danny Polo on clarinet. He composed the jazz standards “Snowfall” and “I Wish I Had You”.

bonuses.leadin: In this series, the title figure rejects Sarah Young and later lands in Bedlam. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this painting series by William Hogarth depicting the fall of Tom Rakewell.

In the first panel of this other Hogarth series, the bankrupt Earl Squanderfield marries the daughter of the city merchant. In its final scene, their son’s wife poisons herself after her lover kills her husband.
Four works by Hogarth depict “the Humours of” one of these events. Another series about one of these events was painted by George Caleb Bingham.

bonuses.leadin: Many poems in this collection focus on the relationship between the speaker and “jivandevata,” or the “lord of my life.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this collection. Its first poem begins with the line, “Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure.”
This Bengali author wrote Gitanjali, in addition to writing both the Indian and Bengali national anthems.
Tagore also wrote this play strongly based in Hindu mythology, in which the protagonist Nandini opposes a mining operation led by the King of Yakshapuri.

bonuses.leadin: This man fired PATCO union members following the air traffic controllers’ strike. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 40th US president whose economic policies were labeled “trickle-down economics”.
One of the low points of Reagan’s presidency was this scandal, in which the US sold arms to Iran to support Nicaraguan anti-communist rebels.
This man and his nephew Ali Bahramani were the Iranian points of contact during the Iran-Contra Affair. He later became the country’s prime minister from 1989 to 1997.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these syncretic religions.
parts: This Vietnamese syncretic religion venerates Victor Hugo as a saint and believes Earth is the 68th of 72 planets, making it very close to Hell.
This syncretic religion, which partly takes from Catholicism, uses the ifa divination system and followers may be possessed by spirits during the “Mounting of the Horse.”
Adherents of this Jamaican religion worship Jah and often smoke ganja.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about movie salaries. For 10 points each:
parts: A controversy started when a tweet was posted falsely stating that Gal Gadot made $300,000 for her role in Wonder Woman as opposed to this actor’s apparently $14 million rendition of Superman.

Even if that were the case, Gal Gadot still reaped double the profit from her first superhero film when compared to Chris Hemsworth, who is famous for portraying this hammer-swinging Norse god of thunder.

Now that Wonder Woman is a box-office smashing success, Gadot has the ability to do this, which Robert Downey Jr. used to turn his $500,000 payday for Iron Man into $50 million to appear in Marvel’s The Avengers.

bonuses.leadin: This compound, known as qinghao su in Chinese, is often used against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this compound which Tu Youyou (“yo-yo”) isolated to win the 2015 Nobel Prize in Medicine.

The action of artemisinin is thought to be due to an unusual bridge in the compound consisting of this functional group. This functional group is famously present in a rocket propellant along with hydrogen in H2O2.
Artemisinin has effectively replaced this compound as the main treatment for malaria. Stork names a “total synthesis” of this compound, which was originally isolated from the bark of a cinchona tree.

bonuses.leadin: Sukru Kaya set up concentration camps during this event, which also included the Siege of Van. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this extermination campaign carried out by Ottoman leadership against the namesake ethnic group.

This member of the “Three Pashas” who controlled the Ottoman Empire ordered the deportation of Armenian intellectuals on April 24, 1915. Six years later, he was assassinated in Germany by Soghomon Tehlirian.
The Armenian Genocide took place during this global conflict, which ended the Ottoman Empire.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about the color blue in chemistry. For 10 points each:
parts: Seven atoms of iron and eighteen of these ions bind to form the pigment Prussian Blue. The Nazis used the hydrogen compound of this ion in concentration camps.
Copper (II) Sulfate, another bright blue compound, is often a hydrate consisting of this many water molecules. Pyridine also has this many carbon molecules.
This vital blue dye is derived from toluene, and its name refers to the fact that this compound can kill parasites that cause sleeping sickness. This dye was used to discover the blood-brain barrier.

bonuses.leadin: This novel’s protagonist is brought to the Magic Theatre by the saxophonist Pablo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel, apparently based on a manuscript written by Harry Haller.
This German-Swiss author of Demian and Siddhartha wrote Steppenwolf.
Hesse’s The Glass Bead Game centers around the Castalian Joseph Knecht, who gains this title after mastering the titular game.
